subject: Re: [junit] A case for adding logging of assertions to junit
msgSnippet: ... It s the definition of a log:  most of the time, you don t need it, but it s handy if you need to double check something after your tests have run. ... Not
messageBody:
On Mon, Jun 9, 2008 at 8:34 PM, Robert Wenner <robert.wenner@...> wrote:
>
> On Monday 09 June 2008 21:18, Cédric Beust wrote:
> > > If I have to go through umpteen thousand lines of log, I may as well
> > > test everything manually.
> >
> > Nobody says you have to, but the fact that your tests pass doesn't
> > guarantee that you are testing what you think you are testing.
>
> Well. If the log is important, I have to go through it, or I miss
> something important. If it is not important (and I don't have to go
> through it) I can skip it altogether. So what do you mean when you say I
> don't have to go through it?

It's the definition of a log: most of the time, you don't need it,
but it's handy if you need to double check something after your tests
have run.

> > Which is why reports are an integral part of a testing framework.
>
> For BDD, I agree.

Not just for BDD, not sure why you want to single this out.

I know of organizations that commit all the test results (HTML and
others) to databases every day so they can run long-term statistics
and various other metrics over the course of time.

--
Cédric
